translated: The Paṭṭhāna Treatise🔽The reverse order of the law of conditionality, the Triad of the Law of Conditionality

original: Dhammapaccanīyānuloma (4), Dukatikapaṭṭhānapāḷi (3)🔽21.8. Āsavasampayuttaduka, Kusalattika🔽Naāsavasampayuttaṁ nakusalaṁ dhammaṁ paccayā āsavavippayutto kusalo dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.) Hetuyā ekaṁ …pe… avigate ekaṁ.🔽Naāsavasampayuttaṁ naakusalaṁ dhammaṁ paccayā āsavasampayutto akusalo dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.) Hetuyā tīṇi …pe… avigate tīṇi.
analyzed: dhamma paccanīya anuloma duka tika paṭṭhāna pāḷi          na āsava sampayuttam na kusalam dhammam paccayā āsava vippayuttaḥ kusalaḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā saṅkhitta hetuyā ekam pe avigate eka  na āsava sampayuttam na akusalam dhammam paccayā āsava sampayuttaḥ akusalaḥ dhammo uppajjati hetu paccayā saṅkhitta hetuyā tīṇi pe avigate tīṇi
translated: The dyad of associated with the taints, the triad of wholesome🔽With an object associated with the taints and unwholesome as condition, a wholesome object dissociated from the taints arises, by way of root-cause condition. (In brief.) In the root-cause condition, there is one. … In the unhampered condition, there is one.🔽With an object not associated with the taints and unwholesome as condition, an unwholesome object associated with the taints arises, by way of root-cause condition. (In brief.) In the root-cause condition, there are three. … In the unhampered condition, there are three.

original: Naāsavasampayuttaṁ naabyākataṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca āsavavippayutto abyākato dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.) Hetuyā tīṇi, adhipatiyā tīṇi …pe… avigate tīṇi.
analyzed: na āsava sampayuttam na abyākatam dhammam paṭicca āsava vippayuttaḥ abyākataḥ dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā saṅkhitta hetuyā tīṇi adhipatiyā tīṇi pe avigate tīṇi
translated: With an object not associated with the taints and unwholesome as condition, an object dissociated from the taints and indeterminate arises, by way of root-cause condition. (In brief.) In the root-cause condition, there are three. In the predominance condition, there are three. … In the unhampered condition, there are three.
